en: A historically agricultural town Located less than 5 km from Alès, Saint-Christol escaped the industrialization of the Alès region and the mining basin. The town has remained resolutely turned towards agriculture. Over the years, the commune has been able to take advantage of its fertile land by varying its crops. As early as 1709, mulberry trees were planted to feed important silkworm farms. The symbols of Mediterranean agriculture such as the vine and the olive tree are also present in the commune. In addition, dairy farming, market gardening, fruit and cereal production shape the landscape of Saint-Christol.  The remains of the small wine-growing village are grouped around its castle and its 11th century church. This one, rebuilt in 1842 on the ruins of a church burnt down in 1702 by the Camisards, saw its architecture modified and preserves few traces of its power and prestige. The castle of Saint-Christol-lès-Alès sheltered part of the bourgeoisie of Alès, put on the run by Jean Cavalier and his Camisards, during the battle of the Mas de Cauvy.Le Château d'Arène, 11th century Former castle of the 11th century. In the 14th century, it was rebuilt by Raymond de Soucanton, which includes the church of Saint-Martin-d'Arène. To facilitate the access, he fi t built the donkey bridge called "pont d'Arène" doubled today by a flooded bridge to improve the traffic. This castle is private but it is visible from the outside.11th century Montmoirac Castle Located on a hill overlooking the plain of the Gardon, its name would come from Monmirar ("Look" in Occitan), but other origins are advanced by historians. First there would have been a watchtower watching over the Gardon and the Cévennes. This castle, demolished several times and rebuilt in the 11 th century, belonged in particular to the Templars, then in the 13 th century to the Tremolet family who were allied to the lords of Anduze. The Pyramid of Saint-Christol-lès-Alès The Obelisk, called Pyramid, erected in 1777 in honor of Monseigneur de Beauteville, Bishop of Alès, commemorates the modification of the steep roads linking Montpellier, Alès and Anduze into passable paths. Its height is 10 meters 44 without the ball which caps it; that of the base is 2 meters 54, which gives a total height of about 13 meters. The hexagonal base had marble slabs with Latin phrases on all three sides. These marbles were removed in 1793, during the revolution. They were replaced in 1868 by M. Decoeur, a civil engineer, who took the opportunity to restore the octogenarian monument.

Celle-ci, reconstruite en 1842 sur les ruines d’une église incendiée en 1702 par les Camisards, vit son architecture modifiée et conserve peu de traces de sa puissance et de son prestige. Le château de Saint-Christol-lès-Alès abrita une partie de la bourgeoisie d’Alès, mise en fuite par Jean Cavalier et ses Camisards, lors de la bataille du Mas de Cauvy.Le Château d’Arène, XIe siècle Ancien château du XI e siècle. Au XIV e siècle, ce dernier est reconstruit par Raymond de Soucanton qui y englobe l'église Saint-Martin-d'Arène. Pour en faciliter l'accès, il fi t construire le pont à dos d'âne dit « pont d'Arène » doublé aujourd'hui d'un pont noyé pour améliorer la circulation. Ce château est privé mais il est visible de l'extérieur.Le Château de Montmoirac, XI e siècle Situé sur une hauteur qui domine la plaine du Gardon, son nom viendrait de Monmirar (“Regarder” en occitan), mais d’autres origines sont avancées par les historiens. Il y aurait d’abord eu une tour de guet surveillant le Gardon et les Cévennes. Ce château, démoli à plusieurs reprises et reconstruit au XI e siècle, a appartenu notamment aux Templiers, puis au XIII e siècle à la famille Tremolet qui étaient alliés aux seigneurs d'Anduze. Ce château est privé mais il est visible de l'extérieur.La Pyramide de Saint-Christol-lès-Alès L’Obélisque, appelé Pyramide, érigé en 1777 en l’honneur de Monseigneur de Beauteville, évêque d’Alès, commémore la modification des voies abruptes reliant Montpellier, Alès et Anduze en chemins carrossables. Sa hauteur est de 10 mètres 44 sans la boule qui la coiffe ; celle du socle est de 2 mètres 54, ce qui donne une hauteur totale de l’ordre de 13 mètres. Le socle hexagonal portait sur les 3 côtés des plaques de marbre avec des phrases en latin. Ces marbres furent arrachés en 1793, lors de la révolution. Ils furent replacés en 1868 par M. Decoeur, ingénieur des Ponts et chaussées, qui en en profita pour restaurer le monument octogénaire.

en:
A historically agricultural villageLocated less than 5 km from Alès, Saint-Christol escaped the industrialization of the Alès region and the mining basin. The town has remained resolutely turned towards agriculture. Over the years, the town has taken advantage of its fertile land by varying its crops. As early as 1709, mulberry trees were planted to supply important silkworm farms. The symbols of Mediterranean agriculture such as the vine and the olive tree are also present in the commune. In addition, dairy farming, market gardening, fruit growing and cereal growing make up the landscape of Saint-Christol
The remains of the small wine-producing village are grouped around its castle and its 11th century church. The latter, rebuilt in 1842 on the ruins of a church burned in 1702 by the Camisards, saw its architecture modified and retains little trace of its power and prestige. The castle of Saint-Christol-lès-Alès sheltered part of the bourgeoisie of Alès, put to flight by Jean Cavalier and his Camisards, during the battle of Mas de Cauvy.

The Castle of Arène, 11th century
Old castle of the XI th century. In the 14th century, it was rebuilt by Raymond de Soucanton, who included the church of Saint-Martin-d'Arène. To facilitate access, he built the bridge with a hogback called "Pont d'Arène", which is now doubled by a drowned bridge to improve traffic. This castle is private but it is visible from the outside.

The Castle of Montmoirac, 11th century
Situated on a hill overlooking the Gardon plain, its name comes from Monmirar ("Look" in Occitan), but other origins are put forward by historians. At first, there would have been a watchtower watching over the Gardon and the Cevennes. This castle, demolished several times and rebuilt in the 11th century, belonged to the Templars, then in the 13th century to the Tremolet family who were allied to the lords of Anduze. This castle is private but it is visible from the outside.

The Pyramid of Saint-Christol-lès-Alès
The Obelisk, called Pyramid, erected in 1777 in honor of Monseigneur de Beauteville, bishop of Alès, commemorates the modification of the steep roads linking Montpellier, Alès and Anduze into carriage roads. Its height is 10.44 metres without the ball on top; the height of the base is 2.54 metres, which gives a total height of about 13 metres. The hexagonal base had marble slabs with Latin phrases on all three sides. These marbles were torn off in 1793, during the revolution. They were replaced in 1868 by Mr. Decoeur, engineer of the Ponts et Chaussées, who took the opportunity to restore the octogenarian monument.

Ancien château du XI e siècle. Au XIV e siècle, ce dernier est reconstruit par Raymond de Soucanton qui y englobe l'église Saint-Martin-d'Arène. Decoeur, ingénieur des Ponts et chaussées, qui en en profita pour restaurer le monument octogénaire.
